Award.AwardTitle: ABR: Socially Monogamous Pairing: Mechanisms and Memory
Award.AbstractNarration: Exclusive male-female pairbonds (socially monogamous mating systems) are seen in only a few kinds of mammals and in some humans, but are a very common reproductive arrangement in birds. Yet almost nothing is known about the internal mechanisms (neurohormones, brain systems) for pairing in birds. Using a common laboratory species, the zebra finch, that forms long-lasting pair relationships, the project aims to discover these mechanisms as they operate at three different life stages to promote socially monogamous pairing: (1) early in life in nestlings when the strong tendency to form close affiliations with family members begins, (2) during juvenile life when the birds first become more interested in the opposite sex than in the parents, and (3) following adult loss of the mate (through death) when a new pair relationship with a new partner can occur. The project is aimed at determining the physiological mechanisms that promote these pair bonding behaviors. Experiments are designed to specifically test the potential involvement of neuropeptides, such as oxytocin, and the adrenal "stress" hormone, corticosterone, in facilitating pair bonding. The project will also investigate the role of corticosterone in the ability of the birds to remember and prefer their first partner even after a long period of separation. Overall, the project will solve a long-standing mystery "what makes birds like zebra finches form strong pair bonds?" It will suggest mechanisms that might apply to the thousands of other socially monogamous birds and more generally to other vertebrates. It will provide new information on mechanisms acting in birds that can be compared with mechanisms operating in socially monogamous mammals, and thus, has the potential to increase understanding of how brains and hormones produce close relationships in all animals, including humans. The project will provide training of students at all levels and will include specific activities to recruit and train women and underrepresented minorities for scientific research careers. The work will be disseminated to the public through general audience publications, a web site, and through outreach programs to middle school girls and local K-12 biology teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wild animals are tremendously diverse in their arrangements for mating and producing surviving young. Of great interest to neuroscientists are the brain and hormone bases of successful reproductive behavior in species that form close male-female relationships (pair bonds) where the pairs cooperate to raise the young (biparental care). Both the pair bonds and the biparental care provide exciting opportunities to discover brain and hormone systems for positive (prosocial) behavior. Most research thus far has focused on a few species of mammals, mainly rodents, yet it is birds that provide the most abundant examples of such behavior, with over 90% of species forming pairs that engage in biparental care. The overarching goal of the project was to capitalize on this common characteristic of birds through a systematic series of experiments to discover some of the neurohormonal bases of their pairing and parental behavior.  The subjects were zebra finches, small birds that form monogamous pairs and breed very successfully in laboratory aviaries. The zebra finch genome was sequenced some years ago and the species is widely used in neuroscience and behavioral research.  Zebra finches belong to the songbird group, the largest limb of the bird family tree and by far the largest species group among terrestrial vertebrates.

One of our key questions concerned the oxytocin family peptide neurohormones oxytocin and vasopressin, which have been shown to be important in pairing and parental behavior in rodents. Are these important in birds like zebra finches, and at what life stage? We found that actions of vasopressin during the first week of life were important for organizing the normal development of juvenile social behavior (interactions with the parents) and for organizing the later adult behavior involved in maintaining a pair relationship. A big and exciting surprise was how important those actions of vasopressin in early life also turned out to be for the young males to learn songs properly from their fathers and sing normal songs when they became adults. Peptide neurohormones of the oxytocin family had never before been known to be involved in the social learning of communication signals.

Another key question was whether pituitary prolactin, known to be a parental behavior hormone in mammals and doves, was also a parental behavior hormone in songbirds like zebra finches. We found that prolactin was elevated in both sexes beginning in late incubation, shortly before the chicks hatch, that the elevation was greater once the pairs were experienced breeders, and that pairs with higher prolactin had more surviving chicks. We found that substantially lowering prolactin with a drug greatly reduced care of chicks (feeding and brooding), confirming that prolactin is important for parental behavior. We also found that elevated prolactin was not absolutely necessary for the birds to care for chicks, because a majority of birds with nests and eggs, but that did not yet have chicks or elevated prolactin, nonetheless fed and brooded foster chicks placed in their nests.

Although the main focus of the project was on the family life of a songbird, we were also able to develop a second bird species, the king quail, as a promising example for the study of pair bonds and their brain and hormone bases. King quail are in the chicken-like bird group and are related to Japanese quail. Among birds, Japanese quail have been the primary subjects for the study of brain and hormone mechanisms for sexual behavior (mating, copulation).  They are famously sexually active but do not engage in any of the pair bond behavior such as huddling together and preening each other that pair bonded rodents and birds show. King quail, on the other hand, had been anecdotally reported to be pair-forming birds with strong pair bonds. In a series of experiments, we found this to be the case and established convenient testing procedures for readily eliciting the behavior. The contrast between these two quail species opens up exciting new possibilities for discovering mechanisms of pair bonding by comparing their brains.

Thus the project led to multiple new insights into the important fitness-enhancing prosocial behaviors of pairing and parental care. The results contribute to a better understanding of the family life of birds and, where they are similar to results from pair-forming rodents, also increase confidence in the generality of those results. In addition to these scientific insights, the project also provided valuable training and career development opportunities for both undergraduate and graduate students, a majority of whom were women, including several Asian Americans and Hispanic Americans. The lab team also engaged in public outreach by participating each year in Expanding Your Horizons, a program of science workshops for middle school girls, educating them about the wonders of brains and inspiring an interest in biology and neuroscience.
